Hi,
	I was thinking about something like this about a year ago.  But I was 
inspired by some folk doing artificial life work rather than NN.  e.g. one 
of them (I'll try to find the reference) had a system which essentially 
evolved systems of partial differential equations.  I think he followed a 
complexification process not dissimilar to NEAT.

e.g. he had "substances" and "catalysts" each substance was a string of 
numbers and each catalyst worked by joining or splitting substances based 
on a match between part of the sequence of the substance and a sequence 
stored on the catalyst.

Thus, he might have:

S1 + S23 -> S123

catalyzed by:

Join1-23

[[leading to PDEs of d[S1]/dT = -[S1].[S23].k.[Join1-23], d[S123]/dT = 
[S1].[S23].k.[Join1-23] etc etc]]

Which would also catalyze.

S41 + S234 -> S41234 etc

--

He was trying to evolve processes similar to those seen in developmental 
biology.  e.g. where an initially homogenous field of cells develops, first 
orientations (posterior vs anterior, dorsal vs ventral etc), then layers 
(it's not a simple as "gut", "skin", "between" but a bit like that) and 
finally organs, limbs etc.

So I think he started with an square grid of cells.  With a separately 
measured concentration of each chemical for each cell, a slow leak of some 
chemicals from cell to cell for intracellular signalling, and some source 
of initial asymmetry, like one slightly random starting concentration; 
concentration gradients across the grid in X and Y; one cell with a little 
of one chemical in it.

The system of PDEs can then be evaluated to simulate the evolution of the 
system over time.  All sorts of phenomena can be reproduced in such a 
system, oscillators, amplification, latches, threshold triggers, ...

I forget exactly what he was evolving for, but the idea that occurred to me 
was to read out three of the chemicals as colours and then select 
individuals for resemblance to a target picture.  You could then evolve a 
set of PDE which generated an image.  You can then imagine all sorts of fun 
experiments, such as varying the grid size, or changing the starting 
conditions from completely asymmetric to periodic.

--

Hmm, not sure I have explained that at all well, however...

The point where this becomes relevant to Mattias' program is that this 
particular theoretical view of developmental biology works in a world very 
like an array of pixels (only with more than three colours on each 
point).  The result from that work, (and from more general CA work) is that 
a single expression evaluated on each pixel, however complex, is not enough 
to create really sophisticated structures.  For complex stuff, you need an 
iterated function, and for the most configurable behaviour, you need some 
communication between adjacent points (so they can do things like "are you 
sky, then I'll be sky as well").

	That was the sort of thing I was wondering about, and I see no reason why 
it would not work just was well if it used ANN to iterate a cell from T to 
T+1 than if it were using PDEs.

	Ian
